To authorize the use of United States Armed Forces against the Islamic State of Iraq and the
			 Levant.

text.#text: This joint resolution may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: that—

text.#text: It is the sense of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has rightly committed limited forces in Iraq to protect United States diplomatic and
			 military personnel against the threat of the Islamic State of Iraq and the
			 Levant (

text.#text: the
the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: should be commended for working with

allies to
			 form a coordinated world response to the threat of ISIL;

text.#text: the

determines that it is necessary to use the United States Armed Forces against
			 ISIL, the

text.#text: if the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
prior to pursuing a multilateral
			 military campaign against ISIL;

text.#text: should seek consensus in the

should endeavor to form a coalition of allies as broadly based as practicable to support and
			 participate with the United States Armed Forces; and
should seek equal participation and assistance from members of the Arab League; and

although military intervention might be necessary to significantly disrupt and degrade ISIL’s
			 activities and operational capabilities in Iraq and Syria, a negotiated
			 political solution among ethnic groups is the only sure solution to end
			 sectarian violence and reach permanent peace.

text.#text: A resolution described in subsection (a) shall be considered in the

to move to
			 proceed to the consideration of the resolution. All points of order
			 against the resolution (and against consideration of the resolution) are
			 waived. Such a motion is privileged and is not debatable. An amendment to
			 the motion is not in order. It shall not be in order to move to postpone
			 the motion or to proceed to the consideration of other business. A motion

text.#text:
On or after the first legislative day after the day on which such a resolution is introduced, it is
			 in order (even though a previous motion to the same effect has been
			 disagreed to) for any Member of the

Debate on the resolution shall be limited to not more than a total of 20 hours, which shall be
			 divided equally between the majority leader and the minority leader or
			 their designees. A motion to further limit debate is not debatable. An
			 amendment to, or motion to recommit, the resolution is not in order.

Immediately following the conclusion of the debate on the resolution, the vote on final passage of
			 the resolution shall occur.

A motion to reconsider the vote by which the resolution is agreed to or disagreed to is not in
			 order.

text.#text: Appeals from the decisions of the Chair relating to the application of the rules of the

header.#text: Action on measure from other house

text.#text:
If, before the passage by one House of a resolution of that House described in subsection (a), that
			 House receives from the other House a resolution described in subsection
			 (a), then the following procedures shall apply:

The resolution of the other House shall not be referred to a committee and may not be considered in
			 the House receiving it except as provided in subparagraph (B)(ii).
With respect to a resolution described in subsection (a) of the House receiving the resolution—

the procedure in that House shall be the same as if no resolution had been received from the other
			 House; but
the vote on final passage shall be on the resolution of the other House.

Upon disposition pursuant to paragraph (1)(B)(ii) of a resolution described in subsection (a) that
			 is received by one House from the other House, it shall no longer be in
			 order to consider such a resolution that was introduced in the receiving
			 House.

quote.#tail: is a calendar day on which that House is in session.

text.#text: At least once every 60 days after the date of the enactment of this joint resolution, the

shall consult on a regular basis with the congressional committees of jurisdiction to

			 resolution in either public or closed sessions.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Authorization for Use of Military Force Against ISIL Resolution/s:9

text.#text: This joint resolution and the authorities under this joint resolution (other than

Whereas the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) has committed gruesome atrocities in Iraq
			 and Syria;

Whereas ISIL has been instigating sectarian violence that threatens the stability of the Middle
			 East region and the national security interest of the United States;

Whereas ISIL has directly threatened the United States and has kidnapped and killed United States
			 citizens in Syria;

Whereas such acts continue to pose an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security and
			 foreign policy of the United States;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
authorized a
			 series of limited airstrikes in Iraq to protect United States personnel
			 and support certain humanitarian operations; and

requires authorization by the
